s2.title: Building on Windows using Microsoft Visual C++
s2.p: &XercesCName; source distribution comes with Microsoft Visual C++ projects and solutions to help you build &XercesCName;. The following describes the steps you need to build &XercesCName;.

s3.title: Building &XercesCName; library
s3.p: To build &XercesCName; from the source distribution (using MSVC), you will need to open the solution containing the project. If you are building your application, you may want to add the &XercesCName; project inside your application's solution.
The solutions containing the &XercesCName; project files and all other samples are in the following sub-directories in the &XercesC3SrcInstallDir; directory:
Once you have the solution open, you need to build the project marked XercesLib. You can select Debug/Release, Static/DLL, and, for VC8, 32/64 bit builds using the Configuration Manager dialog.
If you want to include the &XercesCName; project into your own solution, you need to pick up:
You must make sure that you are linking your application with the &XercesC3WindowsLib;.lib library (or Debug/Static version of it and also make sure that the associated DLL is somewhere in your path.
s3.note: If you are linking your application to a static library, then you will need to compile your application with the XML_LIBRARY preprocessor define in order to turn off the DLL import/export mechanism. This is also the case for the Mingw-msys platform.
If you are working on the AlphaWorks version which uses ICU, you must have the ICU data DLL named icudata.dll available from your path setting.

If the library is built with the ICU message loader, or message catalog loader, then you need to make sure the XERCESC_NLS_HOME environment variable points to the $XERCESCROOT/msg directory where the message files reside.

s3.title: Building samples
s3.p: If you are using the source package, inside the same solution (xerces-all.dsw or xerces-all.sln), you'll find several other projects. These are for the samples. Select all the samples and right click on the selection. Then choose "Build (selection only)" to build all the samples in one shot.

s2.title: Building on UNIX/Linux/Mac OS X platforms
s2.p: &XercesCName; uses GNU make to build the libraries and samples. You must first make sure you have GNU make installed on your system before proceeding. On some platforms GNU make is called gmake instead of make. If you do not have GNU make, ask your system administrator to get it for you.
Do not jump into the build directly before reading this. Spending some time reading the following instructions will save you a lot of wasted time and support-related e-mail communication.

Differences between the UNIX platforms: The description below is generic, but as every programmer is aware, there are minor differences within the various UNIX flavors the world has been bestowed with. The one difference that you need to watch out in the discussion below, pertains to the system environment variable for finding libraries. On Linux and Solaris, the environment variable name is called LD_LIBRARY_PATH, on AIX it is LIBPATH, on Mac OS X it is DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH, while on HP-UX it is SHLIB_PATH. The following discussion assumes you are working on Linux, but it is with subtle understanding that you know how to interpret it for the other UNIX flavors.

s3.title: Setting build environment variables
s3.p: Before doing the build, you must first set your environment variables to pick-up the compiler. While the first one is probably set for you by the system administrator, just make sure you can invoke the compiler. You may do so by typing the compiler invocation command without any parameters (e.g. xlc_r, or g++, or cc) and check if you get a proper response back.

s3.title: Building &XercesCName; library
s3.p: As mentioned earlier, to build &XercesCName; from the source distribution, you must be ready with the GNU tools like autoconf and gmake before you attempt the build.

The autoconf tool is required on only one platform and produces a set of portable scripts (configure) that you can run on all other platforms without actually having the autoconf tool installed everywhere. In all probability the autoconf-generated script (called configure) is already in your src/xercesc directory. If not, type:

This generates a shell-script called configure. It is tempting to run this script directly as is normally the case, but wait a minute. Even if you are using the default compilers like gcc and g++ you need to make some decisions about what components you want to build into the library.
You need to specify one options from each category; not specifying one will instruct configure to pick the best choice available:
Net Accessor (used to read data from HTTP sources):

ol.li: --enable-netaccessor-winsock Uses WinSock (Windows-only, either Cygwin or MinGW)

s3.p: Message Loader (used to store the strings of the error messages):

ol.li: --enable-msgloader-inmemory Stores the messages in C++ arrays
--enable-msgloader-icu Stores the messages using ICU resource bundles
--enable-msgloader-iconv Stores the messages in a iconv message catalog

s3.p: Transcoder (used to convert strings between UTF-16 and any other supported encoding):

ol.li: --enable-transcoder-windows Uses Windows APIs (Windows-only, either Cygwin or MinGW)

s3.p: Thread support is enabled by default too; you can use --disable-threads to remove it.

If you need to specify a compiler (because more than one is found in the PATH, or because it has been renamed to a non-standard name), you should set the environment variables CXX and CC before invoking configure.
If you need special compiler or linker options, define the environment variables CXXFLAGS and LDFLAGS.

s2.title: Building on Windows using Cygwin

p.em: Do not jump into the build directly before reading this.

s2.p: &XercesCName; may be built in the Cygwin environment for use by Cygwin applications. As with the UNIX platforms, &XercesCName; on Cygwin uses GNU tools. Therefore, with a couple of notable exceptions, &XercesCName; on Cygwin is built using the same instructions as the UNIX platforms. The build environment variable XERCESCROOT must be set to the proper path containing the &XercesCName; sources and runConfigure must be run with the "-p cygwin -c gcc -x g++" arguments.

Cygwin's GCC also has the ability to build MinGW targeted binaries. This is supported via the -mno-cygwin compiler switch. In that case the arguments to runConfigure should be '-p mingw-msys -c gcc -x g++ -z -mno-cygwin -l -mno-cygwin -C --host=i686-mingw32'. Note that both the compiler and linker flags need to be set.

Also note that Cygwin is different from the UNIX platforms in the way that it finds libraries at run time. While UNIX platforms may use the environment variable LD_LIBRARY_PATH, Cygwin uses the PATH environment variable.

By default, autoconf on Cygwin and MinGW/MSYS doesn't build shared libraries, even if configure will detect it's possible; you will have to force it by specifying the LDFLAGS=-no-undefined option to configure

There is an issue with the gcc/g++ compiler version 2.95, where C++ exceptions thrown from a DLL will cause the application to crash, regardless of whether there is a "catch" statement. This bug doesn't occur in tests using gcc 3.1 or 3.2, so it is recommended that you use gcc 3.1 or higher.

s2.title: Building on Windows using MinGW

p.em: Do not jump into the build directly before reading this.

s2.p: &XercesCName; may be built in the MinGW-MSYS environment for use by MinGW applications. As with the UNIX platforms, &XercesCName; on MinGW uses GNU tools. Therefore, with a couple of notable exceptions, &XercesCName; on MinGW is built using the same instructions as the UNIX platforms. The build environment variable XERCESCROOT must be set to the proper path containing the &XercesCName; sources and runConfigure must be run with the "-pmingw-msys -cgcc -xg++" arguments. It is also possible to build &XercesCName; libraries for MinGW using Cygwin. For more information on how to do this see the Building on Windows using Cygwin section.

Note that MinGW is different from the UNIX platforms in the way that it finds libraries at run time. While UNIX platforms may use the environment variable LD_LIBRARY_PATH, MinGW uses the PATH environment variable.

When linking against the static version of &XercesCName;, be sure to use the '-DXML_LIBRARY' compiler flag. Otherwise the functions in the header files will be marked as to be imported from a DLL and the linker will fail.
Also note that you can run into a bug found in older MinGW's dllwrap utility, which is used by &XercesCName; build system to link DLLs. For more information see the following mailing list post.

There is an issue with the gcc/g++ compiler version 2.95, where C++ exceptions thrown from a DLL will cause the application to crash, regardless of whether there is a "catch" statement. This bug doesn't occur in tests using gcc 3.1 or 3.2, so it is recommended that you use gcc 3.1 or higher.

s2.title: Building on Windows using Borland C++ Builder
s2.p: &XercesCName; source distribution comes with Borland C++ Builder 6 projects to help you build &XercesCName;. The following describes the steps you need to build &XercesCName;.

s3.title: Building &XercesCName; library
s3.p: The library and demo projects are all contained in the Xerces-all project group:
Each project in the group refers a directory below \Xerces-all. For example, the XercesLib project files are contained in the directory

To build any project, open the project manager. Double click on the project name. Then select "Project|Build" from the menu. For example, double click on XercesLib.dll in the manager. Then select "Project|Build XercesLib" from the menu.
Once the library has been built, include XercesLib.lib with in application's project and place XercesLib.dll somewhere in your path.

s2.title: Building on Windows using Borland C++
s2.p: &XercesCName; source distribution comes with Borland C++ Compiler make files to help you build &XercesCName;. The following describes the steps you need to build &XercesCName;.

ul.li:
make -f Xerces-all.mak
to build the dll (without deprecated DOM API) and tests, or

make -f Xerces-all.mak -DWITHDEPRDOM=Y
to build the dll with deprecated DOM API (approx. 300k larger) and tests

s2.title: Building 64 bit libraries on Windows using Intel C++
s2.p: &XercesCName; source distribution comes with Microsoft Visual C++ NMake Files which work with Intel C++ Compiler. The following describes the steps you need to build &XercesCName; 64 bit binary using Intel C++ Compiler.

s3.title: Building &XercesCName; library
s3.p: &XercesCName; source distribution provides a makefile all.mak which will build everything including samples, tests and the parser library.
s3.source: cd &XercesC3SrcInstallDir;\Projects\Win32\VC6\xerces-all\all nmake -f all.mak "CFG=all - Win64 Release" CPP=ecl.exe
s3.p: If you want to just build the &XercesCName; parser library alone, then
s3.source: cd &XercesC3SrcInstallDir;\Projects\Win32\VC6\xerces-all\XercesLib nmake -f XercesLib.mak "CFG=XercesLib - Win64 Release" CPP=ecl.exe
s3.p: You must make sure that you are linking your application with the &XercesC3WindowsLib;.lib library and also make sure that the associated DLL is somewhere in your path.
